article.title: Nodal and nodeless gap in proximity induced superconductivity: application to monolayer CuO$_2$ on BSCCO substrate

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the red and black squares in Figure 1(d) represent?
choices: Different orbitals of the oxygen atoms
The relative sign of the tunneling matrix element
The position of copper and bismuth atoms
The energy levels of the two bands

multiple_choice_question.text: Which hopping integral is represented by the arrow labeled "tx" in Figure 1(a)?
choices: Hopping between oxygen 2px and 2py orbitals on the same site
Hopping between oxygen 2px orbitals on neighboring sites
Hopping between oxygen 2py orbitals on neighboring sites
Hopping between copper and oxygen orbitals

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1(c) illustrates the tunneling path of:
choices: An electron from CuO(1) to CuO(2) layer.
A hole from CuO(2) to CuO(1) layer.
An electron from CuO(2) to Bi 6s orbital.
A hole from Bi 6s orbital to CuO(1) layer.
The Fermi surface of the system.
The density of states for the two bands.
The band structure of the two-band model.
The superconducting gap as a function of momentum.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the term H represent in Formula (1)?
choices: The kinetic energy of electrons in the CuO(1) layer
The pairing interaction between electrons
The total Hamiltonian of the system
The chemical potential of the electrons

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the dashed lines in Figure 2 represent?
choices: Different values of the hopping integrals
Different electron concentrations
Different pairing strengths
The phase boundary between nodal and nodeless gap

multiple_choice_question.text: According to Figure 2, when only on-site and NNN pairings are considered, for what values of μ is the superconducting gap always V-shaped?
What is the main difference between Figure 2(a) and 2(b)?
choices: Figure 2(b) includes the effect of interorbital pairing.
Figure 2(b) considers a wider range of chemical potentials.
Figure 2(b) includes the 3rd NN pairing term.
Figure 2(b) uses a different set of hopping parameters.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 3 tell us about the effect of the 3rd NN term on the superconducting gap?
choices: It has a negligible effect on the gap.
It suppresses the superconducting gap.
It can change the gap from nodal to nodeless.
It shifts the position of the gap nodes.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is unusual about the position of the nodes in the quasiparticle dispersion shown in Figure 4(c)?
choices: They are located at the Fermi surface.
They are located away from the Fermi surface.
They are located at the Brillouin zone boundary.
They are located at the center of the Brillouin zone.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main factor that determines the A independence of the phase boundary in Figure 4?
choices: The interband pairing term
The intraband pairing term
The value of the chemical potential
The ratio of hopping integrals

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the red and blue regions in Figure 5(b) represent?
choices: Regions with nodal and nodeless superconducting gaps, respectively.
Regions with different hole concentrations.
Regions with different pairing strengths.
Regions with different Fermi surface topologies.
